name: potato production | potato | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/29792/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of potato (fresh matter) in the US state of Idaho at farm, with a harvested moisture content of 79.2%. This dataset includes cultivation of the field prior to planting, field treatments, planting, applications of nutrients and pesticides, fumigant, regulator and desiccant, and harvest (including grading).;The average yield of potato grown in Idaho for the 2010-2021 seasons was 48,869 kg/ha (wet mass) (USDA NASS (2021b)). The dataset reflects the average potato produced in Idaho from 2010 to 2021, inclusive, as that period allows for at least one value from USDA statistics for most parameters and generally three or more.  Potato is a no tillage crop (0% no till, 0% reduced till, 100% conventional tillage) and grown in multiyear rotation, commonly 4-year rotation with other crops. This dataset reflects practices consistent with that.;Area, productivity, use of mineral fertilisers and other agrochemicals, and irrigation inputs are based on farmer data reported to the U.S. Department of Agriculture. This dataset does not consider the use of manure during the production process, although recent studies suggest that the use of manure (green and animal) should be studied and considered, as it could benefit the cultivation of this crop and interest appears to be rising. Lime use is based on soil pH and guidance from agricultural extension offices for potatoes. Field operations and equipment types and fuel use are based on materials provided to growers by the agricultural extension office(s), including farm budgets, and on survey information agricultural extension office(s) collect from growers, in conjunction with row spacing data from USDA Drainage (tile or ditch) is installed on 59.6% based on state-level agricultural survey data from USDA. Irrigation is included based on share of crop irrigated (33.7% over the time period, USDA NASS (2018c)). Chemigation is included in this and is not treated as an additional operation.;Total cropland land use, for all crops, in Idaho decreased by 2% between 1997 and 2017 (NRCS 2020). USDA NASS does not report cropped areas for potato prior to 2010. The crop LCI tool allocates land use change to all crops and activities that grew in the last 20 years in the US, and only to them, according to their respective area increase; crops for which planted area decreased are not attributed LUC impacts or credits. Thus, the amount of Land use change, annual crop is zero for Potato grown in Idaho. The total cropland change 1997 to 2017 was -2.1% for all crops in Idaho (NRCS 2020).;Soil characteristics, including pH, are based on the distribution of soil pH sampling results reported in the 2020 Soil Test Summary (Bruulsema T and Jones J D (2021). The share of acidic soils is likely overestimated as more frequent testing is to be expected on soils having needed lime and thus low pH soils are likely to be more represented amongst the collected samples. No anti-erosion practices are assumed in the dataset; instead, the erosion soil loss reported in the U.S. Natural Resources Conservation Service's Natural Resource Inventory is used.;References:;USDA NASS (2021b) POTATO - PRODUCTION - 2000-2021. US Department of Agriculture (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service. https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov (direct query: https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/results/88567F9F-D7F3-3107-BC9E-BC1236B3DB44);USDA NASS (2018c) 2018 Irrigation and Water Management Survey (2017 Census of Agriculture). US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Online_Resources/Farm_and_Ranch_Irrigation_Survey/index.php;NRCS (2020) Land Cover/use of non-Federal rural land, by State and year, in the 2017 National Resources Inventory. USDA, Natural Resources Conservation Service. http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/Internet/NRCS_RCA/reports/nri_crop_nat.html, https://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/rca/national/technical/nra/rca/text/#NRI%20Cropland;Bruulsema T and Jones J D (2021) Soil Test Summary 2020. Foundation for Agronomic Research and Plant Nutrition Canada present this 2020 summary of soil test levels in North America. Foundation for Agronomic Research, Plant Nutrition Canada. https://soiltest.tfi.org/about/about_soil_test_summaryaccessed August 30, 2021

This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.

This dataset includes cultivation of the field prior to planting, field treatments, planting, applications of nutrients and pesticides, and harvest (including grading). It ends with graded potato at the farm gate, prior to hauling and storage.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/011:Growing of non-perennial crops/0113:Growing of vegetables and melons, roots and tubers

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The valid period covers  2010-01-01 through 2021-12-31 based on primary data sources.  The production volumes, areas and applications are covered by data throughout the time period (annual for production and area, alternate years for applications). Because the specific pesticides used show time-dependent trends, the most recent 3 years of data are used to avoid underweighting the most dominant pesticides currently used and to avoid skewing  impacts based on compounds no longer in use. Field operations are based on current enterprise crop budgets and change little year to year.  Data for manure applications were only available for time periods prior to the valid periord but represent the best available option.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This dataset reflects current practice for potato in Idaho as of 2021.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Mineral fertiliser applications are crop and location (state and sub-state levels) specific for nutrient applied, based on survey data compiled by the USDA National Agricultural Statistics Service. Specific fertilisers are extrapolated from mineral fertiliser applications to  potato in Idaho and market consumption in the US (IFA 2020).  Organic fertiliser types are extrapolated from animal manure use data for  potato in Idaho (state-level) based on data collected by the USDA Economic Reserach Service for 2010, 2005 and 2000 and current materials on lifestock levels. Rotations are based on published analysis and classification of Cropland Data Layer GIS data for 2012-2018 and other sources (Socolar et al 2021).  Corn in a non-repetitive rotation with anything (>4% of land surveyed) else is treated as corn-corn as the most conservative option.  The rotation pattern is assumed to steady throughout the period, consistent with number of years classified.  Data about tillage practices are from crop-specific GIS data for corn encompassing the dataset years (OpTIS 2020).  Soil characteristics, including pH and clay content, are extrapolated from survey year 2017 (Iowa soil survey, ISPAIDver 8.1.1 2019) and taken as valid for the full time period.  data reported 2020 (pH, SOM) and 1995 (clay, slope, approximated with US average farmland slope and clay content), Drainage tile data from 2012 (reported to USDA for the 2012 agricultural census) is extrapolated as valid from that date through the rest of the time period of the dataset and the distribution of drainage is treated as homogenous for all field crops. Machine usage is modelled with Iowa/midwestern US diesel consumption and field operations set out by the regional agricultural extension office and crop budgets (Lazarus 2020, ISU 2015-2021).  Machine sizes (power) are approximate but based on common, recent surveys and equipment analyses (Lazarus 2020).  Transports are modelled with standard distances.  Emissions are calculated with standard methods according to ecoinvent documentation (Nemecek and Schnetzer, 2011. '01 crop production-direct field emissions natural resources' v1.2, August 2011, available at ) and the World Food LCA Database guidelines and the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data is obtained from state, county and national statistics, agricultural extension offices, and published literature. Data for production, yields, applications of NPKS fertilisers, applications of pesticides, row width, and irrigation (if any) was obtained from the US Dept of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service and in most cases provides high-quality data spanning the dataset time period. Field operations and energy use are from enterprise crop budgets provided by local agricultural extensions offices and their farmer survey data. Literature data is used where USDA and agricultural extension guidance and data are not available.

exchanges.description: Emissions of heavy metals to soil are estimated based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production). The balance of heavy metal emissions to soils includes the net change from erosion, leaching, crop removal and fertilizer, manure, lime, planting and deposition.  The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils) Sources for heavy metals contents include: Heavy-metal contents of plant material, maize (mg/kg dry matter, from Freiermuth 2006). ; Leaching of heavy metals to surface water (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where drainage is installed ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Average heavy metal contents in crop soils, mg per kg soil, based on data for Switzerland (from Keller & Desaules, 2001). state and regional erosion rates are from US NRC National Resources Inventory, 2017. and Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (1.7%,) and ditch drainage (4.3%). USDA (2018) 2017 Census of Agriculture, Volume 1, Chapter 2: State Level Data - Table 41.  Land Use Practices:  2017 and 2012 (live table: https://www.nass.usda.gov/Quick_Stats/CDQT/chapter/2/table/41/state/US). US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Full_Report/Volume_1,_Chapter_2_US_State_Level/st99_2_0041_0041.pdf. 2.05E-5 ha/kg application of plant protection product, fumigation (1. pass(es) per year). 
The field is treated with fumigant pre-planting (either in the spring before planting or fall after harvest of prior crop) to control soil-borne fungal diseases and pests. This application is distinct from application of other plant protection products.  Enterprise crop budgets for potato production in Idaho do not disaggregate non-custom field operations (Eborn, 2017), so field operations, particularly tillage, are based on the 1995 report by the same office (Patterson, et al., 1995).  Other information is drawn from related budgets (Painter, et al., 2010; Patterson, 2015).

 Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office (state specific unless otherwise noted) and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance, along with pest management documentation (Hills, et al., 2018, 2020; Hirnyck & Downey, 2006) and summary of practices for commercial production in the US (Belyea, 2010).Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office (state specific unless otherwise noted) and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance, along with pest management documentation (Hills, et al., 2018, 2020; Hirnyck & Downey, 2006) and summary of practices for commercial production in the US (Belyea, 2010).  
Sources:

exchanges.description: Irrigation water not taken up by crop. Calculated by the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool.

2.86E-5 ha/kg fertilising, by broadcaster (1.396 pass(es) per year). 
The dataset has an effective number of passes for application of mineral fertilisers of 14.95: 7.10 N applications on 99.7% of cropped area, 3.50 P applications on 96.0% of cropped area, 2.10 K applications on 90.0% of cropped area, and 3.10 S applications on 84.7% of cropped area (USDA NASS 2021c, data available for 2016 only). The necessary passes used to apply broadcast N are sufficient to supply the necessary PKS so additional passes beyond that for N application are not required. Applications of N are split between anhydrous ammonia and other NPK fertilsers because they are generally applied differently, with different equipment. Anhydrous ammonia application (knifing/injection) is calculated as market share of N that is anhydrous ammonia * total N applications. Other N application is then: total USDA N applications less applications of anhydrous ammonia. The market share of N that is anhydrous ammonia is calculated from fertiliser market group shares crossed with meeting NPKS nutrient demand (here, 80.34%). Thus, the dataset includes 5.69 anhydrous ammonia applications via injection (5.70 * 99.7% of crop area with applied N) and 9.27 other fertiliser applications via broadcast. Enterprise crop budgets for potato production in Idaho do not disaggregate non-custom field operations (Eborn, 2017), so field operations, particularly tillage, are based on the 1995 report by the same office (Patterson, et al., 1995).  Other information is drawn from related budgets (Painter, et al., 2010; Patterson, 2015).

 Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office (state specific unless otherwise noted) and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance, along with pest management documentation (Hills, et al., 2018, 2020; Hirnyck & Downey, 2006) and summary of practices for commercial production in the US (Belyea, 2010). Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office (state specific unless otherwise noted) and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance, along with pest management documentation (Hills, et al., 2018, 2020; Hirnyck & Downey, 2006) and summary of practices for commercial production in the US (Belyea, 2010).  
Sources:
Patterson, Paul and Bohl, William (1995) Potato Production Practices in Southeastern IDAHO. A.E. Exension. 
Eborn, Ben (2017) Southcentral Idaho: Magic Valley. Russet Burbbank Potatoes: Production and Storgae Costs. University of Idaho College of Agricultural and Life Sciences. 
Painter K., Miller J., and Olsen N. (2010) Costs and returns for irrigated organic Russet Burbank potato Production in Southern Idaho. Extension bulletin 876. University of Idaho Extension. https://digital.lib.uidaho.edu/utils/getfile/collection/ui_ep/id/6250.pdf

exchanges.description:
2.4E-3 kg triple superphosphate/kg Potato 
Quantities of specific fertiliser are calculated based on US fertiliser market share and nutrient compositions from the International Fertilizer Association data to meet total nutrient demand N-P-K-S: 286.49--186.4--124.08--55.5 kg/ha  (USDA NASS data for 2010, 2014, 2016). Quantity of specific fertiliser calculated from: average total N application (2010, 2014, 2016, 2018) reported cropped area of specified crop (includes all rotation patterns) and share of fertilisers in U.S. consumption mix (ecoinvent and International Fertilizer Association 2019) times each fertiliser's P2O5 to N ratio (International Fertilizer Association), subtracted from the application rate for the necessary nutrient, and multiplied by the mass of the compound over the mass of P2O5 in the compound.
Sources: 
USDA NASS (2021c) POTATO - APPLICATIONS, MEASURED IN LB / ACRE / YEAR, AVG (fertilizer and pesticides, amount, number of applications) - 2000-2021. US Department of Agriculture (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service. https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov (direct query: https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/results/910944A6-DEB0-3216-B6B4-F5BA47F1D217); Ecoinvent U.S. consumption mix for N fertilisers, from IFA data; IFA (2021) Nutrient content in percentage - IFA Fertilizer Converter. exchanges.description: Land occupation per year (annual growing season).   6.1  million tonnes from  2017-2021 on .1 million ha planted and .2 million ha harvested. Thus occupation is 0.205 ha/t or 2046.286 m2/t (0.2.046m2/kg). This overall land use is split into irrigated ( 33.68% ) and non-irrigated ( 66.32% ) based on agricultural census data ( USDA NASS ) 6.89E-2 m2 planted/kg harvested potato of irrigated land, and 1.36E-1 m2 planted/kg harvested potato of non-irrigated land

Each planted hectare uses 2,465.87 kg seed (5.05E-2 kg/kg Potato). Treated seed. This value is taken from guidance (enterprise crop budget) for potato production in Idaho (Painter, et al., 2010) and average spacing and seed potato size (Belyea S. et al 2010). The dataset assumes conventional seed potato as opposed to genetically modified varieties. While there are some varieties of modified potato authorized in the US, they have limited availability and minor uptake (USDA 2021). The uncertainty parameters are calculated from the uncertainty on the yield and the  guidance variation from guidance for all states. 
Sources:
Painter K., Miller J., and Olsen N. (2010) Costs and returns for irrigated organic Russet Burbank potato Production in Southern Idaho. Extension bulletin 876. University of Idaho Extension. https://digital.lib.uidaho.edu/utils/getfile/collection/ui_ep/id/6250.pdf

Application of limestone to raise soil pH, 63.44 kg/ha (1.3E-3 kg/kg Potato), calculated as (mass of lime applied to treated acres (2 t/treated ha)) * fraction of crop area treated with lime (6.42%, from soil grid level soil pH values (ISPAID8.1.1; USDA NASS) / (5  years between applications, based on Mallarino A P, Pagani A, Sawyer J E 2011). 
Lime is applied to all soils with pH below 6, and to high subsoil pH soils with pH between 6.5 and 6, based on expert guidance (J.E. Sawyer 2020). Cropped area needing liming is determined from grid level (sub-county level) data for soil pH and formation type (ISPAID8.1.1), weighted with county-level production data (NASS). The increase in pH with lime application remains dominant through at least 4 years from application (Mallarino A P, Pagani A, Sawyer J E 2011).
Sources: 
Iowa Soil Survey & Digital Soil Data: ISPAID. Version 8.1.1 (2017). https://www.extension.iastate.edu/soils/ispaid; Sawyer, J.E (2020) Presentation "Soil pH and Liming". Cooperative Extension Service, Iowa State University of Science and Technology.  http://www.agronext.iastate.edu/soilfertility/info/SoilpHandLiming2020.pdfaccessed October 1, 2021; Mallarino A P, Pagani A, Sawyer J E (2011) Corn and soybean response to soil pH level and liming. Paper presented at the 2011 Integrated Crop Management Conference. Iowa State University.Cooperative Extension Service, Iowa State University of Science and Technology. https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/128983337.pdfaccessed November 17, 2021

4.09E-5 ha/kg tillage, cultivating, chiselling (2. pass(es) per year). 
 Enterprise crop budgets for potato production in Idaho do not disaggregate non-custom field operations (Eborn, 2017), so field operations, particularly tillage, are based on the 1995 report by the same office (Patterson, et al., 1995).  Other information is drawn from related budgets (Painter, et al., 2010; Patterson, 2015).

 Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office (state specific unless otherwise noted) and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance, along with pest management documentation (Hills, et al., 2018, 2020; Hirnyck & Downey, 2006) and summary of practices for commercial production in the US (Belyea, 2010).  Potato is a full tillage crop. 
Sources:
Patterson, Paul and Bohl, William (1995) Potato Production Practices in Southeastern IDAHO. A.E. Exension. 
Eborn, Ben (2017) Southcentral Idaho: Magic Valley. Russet Burbbank Potatoes: Production and Storgae Costs. University of Idaho College of Agricultural and Life Sciences. 
Painter K., Miller J., and Olsen N. (2010) Costs and returns for irrigated organic Russet Burbank potato Production in Southern Idaho. Extension bulletin 876. University of Idaho Extension. https://digital.lib.uidaho.edu/utils/getfile/collection/ui_ep/id/6250.pdf
Patterson, Paul (2015) 2014 Cost of Potato Production Study for Colorado, Idaho, Washington and Wisconsin. University of Idaho College of Agricultural and Life Sciences. 
Hills, Karen, et al (2020) Improving Soil Health in Pacific Northwest Potato Production: a Review. American Journal of Potato Research. https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s12230-019-09742-7
Hirnyck, Ronda & Downey, Lisa (2006) Pest Management Strategic Plan for Pacific Northwest Potato Production - REVISION. 
Hills, Karen, et al (2018) Safeguarding Potato Cropping Systems in the Pacific Northwest Through Improved Soil Health. Washington State University. 
Belyea S. et al (2010) Commercial Potato Production in North America. The Potato Association of America. 
Galinato, Suzette (2019) 2019 Cost Estimates of Producing Fresh and Processing Potatoes in Washington. Washington State University.

exchanges.description:
CO2 emissions from use of urea fertilisers and lime, 91.863 kg/ha (1.88E-3 kg/kg Potato): 18.01 kg/ha from lime and 73.85 kg/ha from urea and urea ammonium nitrate . 
Emissions are calculated following the IPCC NIR Guidelines, §11.3 and §11.4, using IPCC NIR equations 11.12 (lime) and 11.13 (urea) (mass of lime/urea * emissions factor for lime/urea) with Tier 1 emissions factors (IPCC 2006b).  EF limestone = 0.12 kg CO2-C/kg limestone (0.06-0.12, uniform) and EF urea = 0.2 kg CO2-C/kg urea (0.1-0.2, uniform) applied to both urea and the approximately 35% of UAN that is urea. The result is converted from kg CO2-C to kg CO2 (multiplying by the molar mass of CO2/mass of C in CO2 = 44.01/12)

exchanges.description: Emissions of heavy metals to soil are estimated based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production). The balance of heavy metal emissions to soils includes the net change from erosion, leaching, crop removal and fertilizer, manure, lime, planting and deposition.  The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils) Sources for heavy metals contents include: Heavy-metal contents of plant material, maize (mg/kg dry matter, from Freiermuth 2006). ; Leaching of heavy metals to surface water (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where drainage is installed ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Average heavy metal contents in crop soils, mg per kg soil, based on data for Switzerland (from Keller & Desaules, 2001). state and regional erosion rates are from US NRC National Resources Inventory, 2017. and Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (1.7%,) and ditch drainage (4.3%). Used with potato harvester. The dataset considers 5% harvest debris in all harvesting, digging and grading field operations picked up during harvesting (see, e.g., Galinato, 2019). The inclusion of this debris enables the dataset to account for the energy required to move/transport the additional mass extracted during the harvesting.  Enterprise crop budgets for potato production in Idaho do not disaggregate non-custom field operations (Eborn, 2017), so field operations, particularly tillage, are based on the 1995 report by the same office (Patterson, et al., 1995).  Other information is drawn from related budgets (Painter, et al., 2010; Patterson, 2015).

 Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office (state specific unless otherwise noted) and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance, along with pest management documentation (Hills, et al., 2018, 2020; Hirnyck & Downey, 2006) and summary of practices for commercial production in the US (Belyea, 2010).Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office (state specific unless otherwise noted) and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance, along with pest management documentation (Hills, et al., 2018, 2020; Hirnyck & Downey, 2006) and summary of practices for commercial production in the US (Belyea, 2010).

1.74E+2 kg potassium sulfate/kg Potato 
Quantities of specific fertiliser are calculated based on US fertiliser market share and nutrient compositions from the International Fertilizer Association data to meet total nutrient demand N-P-K-S: 286.49--186.4--124.08--55.5 kg/ha  (USDA NASS data for 2010, 2014, 2016). Quantity of specific fertiliser calculated from: average total N application (2010, 2014, 2016, 2018) reported cropped area of specified crop (includes all rotation patterns) and share of fertilisers in U.S. consumption mix (ecoinvent and International Fertilizer Association 2019) times each fertiliser's K2O to N ratio (International Fertilizer Association), subtracted from the application rate for the necessary nutrient, and multiplied by the mass of the compound over the mass of K2O in the compound. The remaining K2O and S demands are met from a mix of ammonium sulfate, potassium nitrate, potassium chloride, and potassium sulfate, the quantities of which are determined by satisfying the demand without adding any additional excess of any nutrient beyond that resulting from assuming the U.S. average mix of N fertilizers; any S demand remaining is met using elemental sulfur. 
Sources:

1.17E-4 ha/kg fertilising, by injection (5.704 pass(es) per year). 
The dataset has an effective number of passes for application of mineral fertilisers of 14.95: 7.10 N applications on 99.7% of cropped area, 3.50 P applications on 96.0% of cropped area, 2.10 K applications on 90.0% of cropped area, and 3.10 S applications on 84.7% of cropped area (USDA NASS 2021c, data available for 2016 only). The necessary passes used to apply broadcast N are sufficient to supply the necessary PKS so additional passes beyond that for N application are not required. Applications of N are split between anhydrous ammonia and other NPK fertilsers because they are generally applied differently, with different equipment. Anhydrous ammonia application (knifing/injection) is calculated as market share of N that is anhydrous ammonia * total N applications. Other N application is then: total USDA N applications less applications of anhydrous ammonia. The market share of N that is anhydrous ammonia is calculated from fertiliser market group shares crossed with meeting NPKS nutrient demand (here, 80.34%). Thus, the dataset includes 5.69 anhydrous ammonia applications via injection (5.70 * 99.7% of crop area with applied N) and 9.27 other fertiliser applications via broadcast. Enterprise crop budgets for potato production in Idaho do not disaggregate non-custom field operations (Eborn, 2017), so field operations, particularly tillage, are based on the 1995 report by the same office (Patterson, et al., 1995).  Other information is drawn from related budgets (Painter, et al., 2010; Patterson, 2015).

 Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office (state specific unless otherwise noted) and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance, along with pest management documentation (Hills, et al., 2018, 2020; Hirnyck & Downey, 2006) and summary of practices for commercial production in the US (Belyea, 2010). Emissions of heavy metals to soil are estimated based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production). The balance of heavy metal emissions to soils includes the net change from erosion, leaching, crop removal and fertilizer, manure, lime, planting and deposition.  The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils) Sources for heavy metals contents include: Heavy-metal contents of plant material, maize (mg/kg dry matter, from Freiermuth 2006). ; Leaching of heavy metals to surface water (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where drainage is installed ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Average heavy metal contents in crop soils, mg per kg soil, based on data for Switzerland (from Keller & Desaules, 2001). state and regional erosion rates are from US NRC National Resources Inventory, 2017. and Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (1.7%,) and ditch drainage (4.3%). USDA (2018) 2017 Census of Agriculture, Volume 1, Chapter 2: State Level Data - Table 41.  Land Use Practices:  2017 and 2012 (live table: https://www.nass.usda.gov/Quick_Stats/CDQT/chapter/2/table/41/state/US). US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Full_Report/Volume_1,_Chapter_2_US_State_Level/st99_2_0041_0041.pdf. Fertilizer, manure and pesticide application rates are based on USDA NASS data.

Emissions of heavy metals to ground water arise from leaching. These emissions are estimated  based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production).  The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils)Sources for heavy metals leaching to groundwater include: Leaching of heavy metals to groundwater (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where no drainage is installed ; the share of leaching to groundwater is calcualted from Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (1.7%,) and ditch drainage (4.3%).
